0: People with OCD may have symptoms of obsessions, compulsions, or both. These symptoms can interfere with all aspects of life, such as work, school, and personal relationships. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Obsessions are repeated thoughts, urges, or mental images that cause anxiety. Common symptoms include: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Fear of germs or contamination NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Unwanted forbidden or taboo thoughts involving sex, religion, and harm NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Aggressive thoughts towards others or self NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Having things symmetrical or in a perfect order NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Compulsions are repetitive behaviors that a person with OCD feels the urge to do in response to an obsessive thought. Common compulsions include: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Excessive cleaning and/or handwashing NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ordering and arranging things in a particular, precise way NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Repeatedly checking on things, such as repeatedly checking to see if the door is locked or that the oven is off NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Compulsive counting NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Not all rituals or habits are compulsions. Everyone double checks things sometimes. But a person with OCD generally: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Can't control his or her thoughts or behaviors, even when those thoughts or behaviors are recognized as excessive NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Spends at least 1 hour a day on these thoughts or behaviors NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Doesn’t get pleasure when performing the behaviors or rituals, but may feel brief relief from the anxiety the thoughts cause NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Experiences significant problems in their daily life due to these thoughts or behaviors NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Some individuals with OCD also have a tic disorder. Motor tics are sudden, brief, repetitive movements, such as eye blinking and other eye movements, facial grimacing, shoulder shrugging, and head or shoulder jerking. Common vocal tics include repetitive throat-clearing, sniffing, or grunting sounds. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Symptoms may come and go, ease over time, or worsen. People with OCD may try to help themselves by avoiding situations that trigger their obsessions, or they may use alcohol or drugs to calm themselves. Although most adults with OCD recognize that what they are doing doesn’t make sense, some adults and most children may not realize that their behavior is out of the ordinary. Parents or teachers typically recognize OCD symptoms in children. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR If you think you have OCD, talk to your doctor about your symptoms. If left untreated, OCD can interfere in all aspects of life. are may contamination your or NEWLINE_CHAR the NEWLINE_CHAR arranging from on cleaning avoiding
